repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Northern Border Environment
            Project and Environmental Structural Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings for the Mexico Northern
            Border Environment Project (NBEP) and the Environmental
            Structural Adjustment Loan Project (EnvSAL I) are as
            follows: Project outcome for NBEP is moderately
            unsatisfactory and for EnvSAL I the outcome is satisfactory;
            sustainability for both projects is satisfactory;
            institutional development impact for both is high; Bank
            performance for NBEP is rated unsatisfactory, while Bank
            performance for EnvSAL I is rated satisfactory; and Borrower
            performance for NBEP is unsatisfactory, while Borrower
            performance for EnvSAL Iis satisfactory. The NBEP and EnvSAL
            I together offer the Bank some important lessons for its
            future assistance in strengthening the capacity of
            environmental institutions and as it tries new lending
            instruments (such as Development Policy Loans) to achieve
            this goal. They are: 1) Quickly capitalizing on narrow
            windows of political opportunity to accelerate the
            Bank's processing o f large environmental
            infrastructure operations can be highly risky, since it can
            lead, as it did under the NBEP, to over-ambitious design,
            inadequately prepared implementing agencies and poor overall
            quality at entry, especially when political considerations
            are allowed to drive the preparation and appraisal
            timetable. 2) Targeting project support for local agencies
            in more direct ways helps them assume more responsibilities
            and contribute in more measurable ways to environmental
            sustainability. This support needs to be concrete and under
            their control. In contrast, "top-down" approaches
            tend to focus on the broader enabling environment, but may
            neglect the lack of skills and resources at local levels. 3)
            In cases where the processing triggers for the programmatic
            loans are different from interim results and final outcomes,
            these triggers should be clearly distinguished in the
            simplified Implementation Completion Reports. 4) Prior
            Government commitment and formal policies as well as a
            time-based plan are crucial prerequisites for the successful
            implementation of Environmental Development Policy Loans.
            Desired policy outcomes and practical constraints need to be
            clear in order to enhance dialogue and promote synergies.

            Border Environment Project (NBEP) and the Environmental

6341127.trustfund:
TF021445-KENYA 2ND AGRICULTURAL SECTOR
            ADJ. OPER.,TF023016-PHRD-BOARDER ENVIRONMENTAL
            MANAGEMENT I,TF023017-PHRD-HAZARDOUS WASTE PROJECT,TF040928-MEXICO: NORTHERN BORDER ENVIRONMENT,TFM21445-KENYA 2ND AGRICULTURAL SECTOR
            ADJ. OPER.,TFS21445-KENYA 2ND AGRICULTURAL SECTOR
            ADJ. OPER.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Northern Border Environment Project
            for Mexico had an unsatisfactory outcome, likely
            sustainability, and high institutional development impact.
            The performance by the borrower was satisfactory, while that
            by the Bank was unsatisfactory. The project was
            substantially changed by the cancellation of investment and
            core infrastructure activities and a revised objective
            focusing on providing technical assistance and strengthening
            the institutional capacity of Border States.  Lessons
            learned, including the following, were in the areas of
            project design and implementation, administrative
            procedures, procurement procedures, and financial resources.
            The project preparation phase should consider possible
            changes financial and economic conditions over the duration
            of the project.  Both project design and implementation need
            to be sufficiently flexible to accommodate changes in
            priorities.  Second tier institutions can be more effective
            in carrying out environmental management activities. Future
            operations should emphasize technical assistance and the
            increased probability of program sustainability associated
            with the Bank's participation.  The project design
            phase should pay attention to the flow of funds to the
            implementing agencies.  A detailed analysis of the
            administrative procedures should be carried out during
            project preparation.  The Operations Manual should
            explicitly describe procedures, including eligible
            expenditures and procurement.  Before effectiveness, details
            of procurement procedures and a project procurement plan
            must be agreed upon.  Capacity building and technical
            assistance on procurement procedures should be made
            accessible throughout project implementation.  The flow of
            financial resources needs to be more agile and direct.
